columns.text: In this exercise, we will apply the concept of international Fisher effect in answering the following questions.

The **international Fisher effect** is a condition stating that the real rates of the countries are *the same*. **Real rates** are the interest rates that are *adjusted for inflation.* On the other hand, **nominal rates** are those are *not adjusted for inflation.*

The exercise give us the formula of **domestic Fisher effect**. It shows us the relationship between the nominal rate, the real rate, and inflation rate. The formula is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{1 + r} &= \dfrac{\text{1 + R}}{\text{1 + h}}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

r = real rate

R = nominal rate

h = inflation rate

## a.

We are asked to determine the nonapproximate form of the international Fisher effect.

Assuming the domestic country is the United States, the formula for the domestic Fisher effect is as follows: 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{1 + $r_{US}$} &= \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{US}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{US}$}}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
Wherein:

$r_{US}$ = real rate in the U.S.

$R_{US}$ = nominal rate in the U.S.

$h_{US}$ = inflation rate in the U.S.

The domestic Fisher effect is not only applicable to United states, it is also applicable to other countries or *foreign countries*. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{1 + $r_{FC}$} &= \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{FC}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{FC}$}}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
Wherein:

$r_{FC}$ = real rate in the foreign country.

$R_{FC}$ = nominal rate in the foreign country.

$h_{FC}$ = inflation rate in the foreign country.

The **international Fisher effect** is a condition stating that the real rates of the countries are *the same*.  Therefore, we will combine the two domestic Fisher effect we created.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{1 + $r_{US}$} &= \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{US}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{US}$}}=\text{1 + $r_{FC}$} = \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{FC}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{FC}$}}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
Wherein:

$r_{US}$ = real rate in the U.S.

$R_{US}$ = nominal rate in the U.S.

$h_{US}$ = inflation rate in the U.S.

$r_{FC}$ = real rate in the foreign country.

$R_{FC}$ = nominal rate in the foreign country.

$h_{FC}$ = inflation rate in the foreign country.

As a conclsuion, the nonapproximate form of the international Fisher effect is as follows: 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{1 + $r_{US}$} &= \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{US}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{US}$}}=\text{1 + $r_{FC}$} = \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{FC}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{FC}$}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

## b.

We are asked to determine the exact form of UIP.

**Interest rate parity** is a condition stating the the difference in interest rate is the *same* as the difference of the percentage in forward exchange rate and spot exchange rate. The formula for interest rate parity is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{t}$} &= \text{$S_{0}$}\times{{\text{[ 1 + ($R_{FC}$ - $R_{US}$)]}}}^t\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

$F_{t}$ =  Forward exchange rate at time *t*

$S_{0}$ = Spot rate

$R_{FC}$ = nominal rate in the foreign country.

$R_{US}$ = nominal rate in the U.S.

Next, **unbiased forward rates** state that the forward rate is equal to the expected future spot rate. To visualize: 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{t}$} &= \text{E($S_{t}$)}
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

$F_{t}$ = Forward exchange rate at time *t*

E($S_{t}$) = Expected future spot rate at time *t*

**Uncovered interest parity** is a condition stating the expected percentage change in the exchange rate is the *same as* the difference in the interest rates. Therefore, its exact form is the combined interest rate parity and unbiased forward rate.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{t}$} = \text{E($S_{t}$)}= \text{$S_{0}$}\times{{\text{[ 1 + ($R_{FC}$ - $R_{US}$)]}}}^t\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

$F_{t}$ =  Forward exchange rate at time *t*

E($S_{t}$) = Expected future spot rate at time *t*


$S_{0}$ = Spot rate

$R_{FC}$ = nominal rate in the foreign country.

$R_{US}$ = nominal rate in the U.S.

As a conclusion, the exact form for UIP is as follows: 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{t}$} = \text{E($S_{t}$)}= \text{$S_{0}$}\times{{\text{[ 1 + ($R_{FC}$ - $R_{US}$)]}}}^t\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

## c.

We are asked to determine the exact form of Purchasing Power Parity.

A **purchasing power parity** refers to the thought that the exchange rate adjusts in order to keep a *constant purchasing power* among the currencies. There are **two forms** of PPP, the *absolute* PPP and *relative* PPP.

A **relative purchasing power parity** refers to the concept that there is a *change in exchange rate* that can be determined by the *difference of the inflation rate* of two countries.  Its formula is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{t})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($h_{FC}$-$h_{US}$)}]^t\\\
\end{aligned}$$

wherein: 

$E(S_{t})$ = Expected exchange rate in *t* periods 

$S_{0}$ = Current spot exchange rate 

$h_{FC}$ = Foreign country inflation rate 

$h_{US}$ = Inflation rate in the US

The exercise give us the a hint to combine the previous answers. The exact form of international Fisher effect is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{1 + $r_{US}$} &= \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{US}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{US}$}}=\text{1 + $r_{FC}$} = \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{FC}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{FC}$}}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
Wherein:

$r_{US}$ = real rate in the U.S.

$R_{US}$ = nominal rate in the U.S.

$h_{US}$ = inflation rate in the U.S.

$r_{FC}$ = real rate in the foreign country.

$R_{FC}$ = nominal rate in the foreign country.

$h_{FC}$ = inflation rate in the foreign country.

Next, the exact form of UIP is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{t}$} = \text{E($S_{t}$)}= \text{$S_{0}$}\times{{\text{[ 1 + ($R_{FC}$ - $R_{US}$)]}}}^t\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

$F_{t}$ =  Forward exchange rate at time *t*

E($S_{t}$) = Expected future spot rate at time *t*


$S_{0}$ = Spot rate

$R_{FC}$ = nominal rate in the foreign country.

$R_{US}$ = nominal rate in the U.S.

According to the international Fisher effect, the real rates of the countries are *the same*. Therefore:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{1 + $r_{US}$} =\text{1 + $r_{FC}$} \\
\end{aligned}$$
\
Wherein:

$r_{US}$ = real rate in the U.S.

$r_{FC}$ = real rate in the foreign country.

Hence, we can eliminate 1 + $r_{US}$ and 1 + $r_{FC}$ from the equations since they are equal. The international Fisher effect equation would be: 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{US}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{US}$}} = \dfrac{\text{1 + $R_{FC}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{FC}$}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

$R_{FC}$ = nominal rate in the foreign country.

$R_{US}$ = nominal rate in the U.S.

$h_{US}$ = inflation rate in the U.S.

$h_{FC}$ = inflation rate in the foreign country.

Combining it with the UIP equation, we can eliminate $R_{US}$ and $R_{FC}$ as well. Hence, the formula will be as follows: 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$F_{t}$} = \text{E($S_{t}$)}= \text{$S_{0}$}\times\left(\dfrac{\text{1 + $h_{FC}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{US}$}}\right)^t\\
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

$F_{t}$ =  Forward exchange rate at time *t*

E($S_{t}$) = Expected future spot rate at time *t*


$S_{0}$ = Spot rate

$h_{US}$ = inflation rate in the U.S.

$h_{FC}$ = inflation rate in the foreign country.

Since the purchasing power parity determines the expected exchange rate in *t* periods or  $E(S_{t})$ , we will not be needing the forward rate in the equation. Therefore, the exact form of Purchasing Power Parity is as follows: 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{E($S_{t}$)}= \text{$S_{0}$}\times\left(\dfrac{\text{1 + $h_{FC}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{US}$}}\right)^t\\
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

E($S_{t}$) = Expected future spot rate at time *t*


$S_{0}$ = Spot rate

$h_{US}$ = inflation rate in the U.S.

$h_{FC}$ = inflation rate in the foreign country.

As a conclusion, the exact form of Purchasing Power Parity is:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{E($S_{t}$)}= \text{$S_{0}$}\times\left(\dfrac{\text{1 + $h_{FC}$}}{\text{1 + $h_{US}$}}\right)^t\\
\end{aligned}$$

Wherein:

E($S_{t}$) = Expected future spot rate at time *t*


$S_{0}$ = Spot rate

$h_{US}$ = inflation rate in the U.S.

$h_{FC}$ = inflation rate in the foreign country.

## d.

We are asked to recalculate the NPV for the Kihlstrom drill bit project using the exact forms for UIP and the international Fisher effect.

The following are given in the Kihlstrom Equipment, which is shown in the section 21.5 of the book.

- The current spot exchange rate for euros is € 0.5.
- The risk-free rate in the United States is 5%.
- The risk-free rate in the Euroland is 7%.
- The discount rate is 10%.

Additionally, we are given the following:

- The project will cost €2 million.
- The cash flows are expected to be €0.9 million per year for the next three years

First, we will determine the NPV using the exact form of UIP. The exact form of UIP is also used in the **home currency approach**. In home currency approach, we will convert all the foreign currency into the home currency, and apply the discount rate to determine the NPV.

Let us compute the exchange rate for Year 1, Year 2,  and Year 3. The formula for the determining the exchange rate is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{t})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^t\\\
\end{aligned}$$

wherein: 

$E(S_{t})$ = Expected exchange rate in *t* periods 

$S_{0}$ = Current spot exchange rate  

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate in foreign country 

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate in the U.S.

First, we will determine the exchange rate for year 1:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{1})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times[ 1+\text{(0.07-0.05)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times[ 1+\text{(0.02)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times( 1.02)^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times1.02\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{ € 0.51}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 1 is **€ 0.51 per $ 1**.

Next, we will determine the exchange rate for year 2:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{2})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times[ 1+\text{(0.07-0.05)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times[ 1+\text{(0.02)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times( 1.02)^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times1.0404\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{ € 0.52}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 2 is **€ 0.52 per $ 1**.

Lastly, we will determine the exchange rate for year 3:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{3})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times[ 1+\text{(0.07-0.05)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times[ 1+\text{(0.02)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times( 1.02)^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{ € 0.5}\times1.06121\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{ € 0.53}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 3 is **€ 0.53 per $ 1**.

Next, we will divide the expected cash flow per year by the expected exchange rate to determine the cash flow in U.S. dollars.  To visualize:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash Flow in \$} &= \dfrac{\text{Cash Flow in € }}{\text{Exchange Rate}}\\[10pt]

\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have converted the expected cash flows into dollars. We need to divide it to the discount rate of 13% so we can get the  present value. The formula is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Present Value } &= \dfrac{\text{Cash Flow in \$ }}{\text{(1 + Discount Rate)}^t}\\[10pt]

\end{aligned}$$

We will now combine the present value from Year 1 to Year 3.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Present Value Y1}&&\$ 1,604,278\\
\text{Present Value Y2}&&1,430,388\\

\text{Present Value Y3}&&\underline{~~~~1,275,817}\\
\text{Total Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{\text{\$ 4,310,483
}}}\\
\end{array}$$

Lastly, we will subtract the cost of the project worth $ 4,000,000 from the present value to get the **net present value**.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Total Present Value}&&\$ 4,310,483\\
\text{Cost of Project}&&\underline{(4,000,000)}\\
\text{Net Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{\text{~~~~~\$ 310,483}}}\\
\end{array}$$
As a conclusion, the net present value (NPV) of the expansion is **$ 310,483** when using the exact form of UIP.

Next, we will determine the NPV using the exact form of international Fisher effect. It is the same as the **foreign currency approach**. In this approach,  we will determine first the required return on foreign investment. After, we will discount it foreign cash flow to determine the NPV in foreign currency. Lastly, we will convert the foreign NPV to dollar NPV.

First, we will determine the difference in the nominal rates using the international Fisher effect. The **international Fisher effect** is a theory stating the real interest rates **are the same** between countries.

The formula of international Fisher effect is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$R_{US}$}-\text{$h_{US}$} &=\text{$R_{FC}$}-\text{$h_{FC}$}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of U.S.

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of a foreign country

$h_{FC}$ = Inflation rate in a foreign country

$h_{US}$ = Inflation rate in a U.S.

Since what we are looking for is the required return in euros, we need to derived the formula as follows: 


$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$R_{Fc}$} &=\text{$R_{US}$}-\text{$h_{US}$}+\text{$h_{FC}$}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of U.S.

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of a foreign country

$h_{FC}$ = Inflation rate in a foreign country

$h_{US}$ = Inflation rate in a U.S.

We will now combine the present value from Year 1 to Year 5.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Present Value Y1}&&\text{€ 803,571}\\
\text{Present Value Y2}&&717,474\\
\text{Present Value Y3}&&\underline{~~~~~~~640,602}\\
\text{Total Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{\text{€ 2,161,647}}}\\
\end{array}$$

Lastly, we will subtract the cost of project worth € 2,000,000 from the present value to get the **net present value**.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Total Present Value}&&\text{€ 2,161,647}\\
\text{Cost of Project}&&\underline{~~(2,000,000)}\\
\text{Net Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{~~~~\text{€ 161,647
}}}\\
\end{array}$$
As a conclusion, the NPV using the exact form of international Fisher effect is **$ 323,294**.
To sum  it all up, we applied the concept of international Fisher effect along in answering the following questions.
